title: Letters from the East: Crusaders, Pilgrims and Settlers in the 12–13th Centuries

container-title: Crusade and Christendom: Annotated Documents in Translation from Innocent III to the Fall of Acre, 1187–1291

publisher: E.J. Costello, University of California Press
title: Arab Historians of the Crusades, tr

container-title: Chronicles of the Crusades, Phoebe Phillips Editions

title: The First Crusade: ‘The Chronicle of Fulcher of Chartres’ and Other Source Materials
The Crusades: Idea and Reality 1095–1274

container-title: The First Crusade: Origins and Impact
title: Useful discussions about source material can be found in the introductions of most texts used in the Documents section, but other important works are: Bull, M.G., ‘The Diplomatic of the First Crusade’
Medieval Charters as a Source for the History of the Crusades’
William of Tyre: Historian of the Latin East

container-title: The Oxford Illustrated History of the Crusades
Jonathan Phillips, ‘Caffaro of Genoa and the Motives of the Early Crusaders’, Religion as an Agent for Change
note: which as its title suggests, concentrates on the capture of the holy city in particular. Jay Rubenstein’s vivid Armies of Heaven: The First Crusade and the Quest for the Apocalypse, Basic Books, New York, 2011 lays important emphasis on the strand of apocalyptic feeling current in contemporary Europe. Peter Frankopan’s The First Crusade: The Call from the East, Bodley Head, London, 2012 adopts the perspective of the Byzantine Empire and makes a full and convincing case for the role of the Greeks in the origins of the crusade. By far the best analysis of events at Jerusalem in 1099 is Benjamin Z. Kedar’s ‘The Jerusalem Massacre of July
title: The origins of the First Crusade are best treated in the work of three authors: Marcus Bull has clearly established the links between the lay nobility and the Church (a key aspect of the background to the crusade) in his Knightly Piety and the Lay Response to the First Crusade
The importance of pilgrimage is emphasised in Bull’s ‘Pilgrimage Origins’
The broader context of eleventh-century society is neatly illuminated in his ‘Origins’
John Cowdrey’s studies have revealed the development of the crusade in papal circles: ‘Pope Urban II’s Preaching of the First Crusade’
Pope Urban and the Idea of the Crusade’

Jonathan Riley-Smith’s work is fundamental in our assessment of the origins of the crusading movement and in trying to understand the motives of the First Crusade. His book, The First Crusade and the Idea of Crusading, Athlone Press
is highly recommended in this context. Much of his work on family connections between crusaders is brought together in The First Crusaders 1095–1131

Two further contributions to the study of the motivation are William J. Purkis, Crusading Spirituality in the Holy Land and Iberia, c.1095–c.1187, Boydell, Woodbridge, 2008 which uncovers the influence of contemporary devotional activities on the crusaders, as well as considering the importance of pilgrimage and the relationship between crusading in Iberia and the Near East

looks at the First Crusade from the perspective of the Italian trading community. Two lively narrative accounts of the progress of the expedition are Tom Asbridge’s The First Crusade: A New History, The Free Press, London, 2004 and Conor Kostick’s The Siege of Jerusalem: Crusade and Conquest in 1099
1099 in the Western Historiography of the Crusades’
The early years of the Frankish East are covered in a variety of works

container-title: Medieval Women: Studies in Church History, Subsidia 1
note: and Melisende as a patron of the arts is amply illustrated in Jaroslav Folda, The Art of the Crusaders in the Holy Land, 1095–1187, Cambridge University Press, Cambridge,
The accession of Prince Raymond is discussed in Jonathan Phillips’s Defenders of the Holy Land: Relations between the Latin East and the West, 1119–87,
title: The clearest overview is certainly contained in Barber’s Crusader States
Murray’s The Crusader Kingdom of Jerusalem, 1099–1125, Prosopographica et Genealogica
is the leading analysis of this period. A detailed study of the foundation of Antioch is Tom Asbridge’s The Principality of Antioch, 1098–1130
The reigns of Fulk and Melisende have been the subject of detailed study by Hans Mayer and his magisterial article, ‘Studies in the History of Queen Melisende of Jerusalem’
is well worth examining. Melisende and her sister Alice are discussed in Bernard Hamilton’s ‘Women in the Crusader States: The Queens of Jerusalem (1100–90)’
An overview of Melisende is in Phillips

container-title: and ‘Abominable Acts: The Career of Zengi’, The Second Crusade: Scope and Consequences
title: The Muslim reaction to the First Crusade and the rise of Zengi are the province of Carole Hillenbrand and her articles, ‘The First Crusade: The Muslim Perspective’, The First Crusade: Origins and Impact
are essential reading. Hillenbrand’s book, The Crusades: Islamic Perspectives
opened out the impact of the crusades in the Near East to a remarkable extent and remains the starting point for this subject

note: Adrian Boas has produced the most up-to-date and effective work on towns in Crusader Archaeology: Material Culture of the Latin East, Routledge, London, 1999, and Jerusalem in the Time of the Crusades, Routledge, London, 2001.
title: is carefully considered in Benjamin Kedar’s ‘Subjected Muslims of the Frankish Levant’, Muslims under Latin Rule 1100–1300
Hanbalis of the Nablus Region in the Eleventh and Twelfth Centuries’
The authority on Frankish rule and settlement in the countryside is Ronnie Ellenblum in his Frankish Rural Settlement in the Latin Kingdom of Jerusalem

note: Easily the best work on the Templars is Malcolm Barber’s The New Knighthood. A History of the Order of
title: One could build a mountain out of the misguided, ill-informed and fictitious books on the military orders; ignore everything outside the publications of serious historians. A fine starting point that covers the orders in the Holy Land, Iberia and the Baltic is Nicholas Morton’s The Medieval Military Orders, 1120–1314

note: Cambridge University Press, between the order and the noble families of Burgundy, Champagne and the Languedoc.
title: The Hospitallers have received succinct treatment in Jonathan Riley-Smith’s Hospitallers: The History of the Order of St John, Hambledon
or greater depth in his The Knights Hospitaller in the Levant, c.1070–1309

An interesting study of the military orders’ activities in the West is Dominic Selwood’s Knights of the Cloister, Boydell, Woodbridge, 1999, while Jochen Schenk’s Templar Families: Landowning Families and the Order of the Temple in France, c.1120–1307
The Second Crusade has been given comprehensive treatment by Jonathan Phillips in his The Second Crusade: Extending the Frontiers of Christendom

note: Bloomsbury, London, 2014, as well as Ralph-Johannes Lilie, Byzantium and the Crusader States, 1095–1204, tr. J.C. Morris and J.E. Ridings, Clarendon Press, Oxford, 1993. An article by Chris Wright, ‘On the Margins of Christendom: The Impact of the Crusades on Byzantium’, in Kostick, Crusades and the Near East,

is a subtle, shorter analysis. The impact of the failure of the Second Crusade is examined extensively in Jonathan Phillips, Defenders of the Holy Land, 1996. The rise of Nur ad-Din and Saladin is given thoughtful coverage in Nikita Elisséeff, ‘The Reaction of the Syrian Muslims after the Foundation of the First Latin Kingdom of Jerusalem’, Crusaders and Muslims in Twelfth-Century Syria,
title: article ‘The Second Crusade as Seen by Contemporaries’
remains important
The Second Crusade: Scope and Consequences
includes a range of articles on many aspects of the expedition and its impact. Penny Cole’s The Preaching of the Crusades to the Holy Land, 1095–1274, Medieval Academy of America
contains a fine analysis of the ideas of St Bernard and Peter the Venerable

remains a foundation for studies of military history. For a top-line analysis of the tactics and effectiveness of the First Crusade, see John France, Victory in the East: A Military History of the First Crusade
Siege warfare is covered in Randall Rogers’s Latin Siege Warfare in the Twelfth Century
and Muslim military practice is considered in Carole Hillenbrand’s The Crusades: Islamic Perspectives
John France’s essay ‘Warfare in the Mediterranean Region in the Age of the Crusades, 1095–1291: A Clash of Contrasts’, in Kostick, Crusades and the Near East
is a fine overview. Crusader castles are discussed in a lively and well-illustrated form in Hugh Kennedy’s Crusader Castles
and in a more thematic manner in Adrian Boas’s Crusader Archaeology
Ronnie Ellenblum’s Crusader Castles and Modern Histories

is a very important volume that blends archaeology and textual work to analyse the phases of crusader castle building and to show how and why they evolved in form and location. The complex relations between Byzantium and crusading armies, and Byzantium and the Latin East are astutely dealt with by Jonathan Harris, Byzantium and the Crusades
The Crusades: Islamic Perspectives
Yehoshua Frenkel’s ‘Muslim Responses to the Frankish Dominion in the Near East, 1098–1291

is well worth reading, as is Suleiman Mourad and James Lindsay’s ‘Ibn ‘Asakir and the Intensification and Reorientation of Sunni Jihad Ideology in Crusader-Era Syria’, Just Wars, Holy Wars and Jihads: Christian, Jewish and Muslim Encounters and Exchanges

A biography of Usama ibn Munqidh is the opportunity for Paul Cobb to pen an interesting and enjoyable insight into the life and times of this prolific writer, Usama ibn Munqidh: Warrior Poet of the Age of the Crusades, One World
The power of the kings of Jerusalem is given provocative, but largely convincing treatment in Steven Tibble’s Monarchy and Lordships in the Latin Kingdom of Jerusalem, 1099–1291
The details of succession to the early kings are considered in Alan Murray, The Crusader Kingdom of Jerusalem

container-title: Deborah Gerish’s article on ‘Gender Theory’ in H. Nicholson, Palgrave Advances in the Crusades
is an important theoretical guide, while the essay collection Gendering the Crusades
title: The role of women on crusade was a subject historians tended to overlook until Natasha R. Hodgson’s Women, Crusading and the Holy Land in Historical Narrative

examined perceptions of women in crusading narratives (mostly written by male clerics, of course), to see how they were treated in such texts and to look at their role in these campaigns, and at home and in the Levant. The work of Danielle Park (2013) offers further close analysis of the role of female regents during the absence of their husbands on crusade

container-title: and Andrew Jotischky’s The Perfection of Solitude: Monks and Hermits in the Crusader States
title: Religious life in the Levant is another relatively neglected subject, but Bernard Hamilton’s The Latin Church in the Crusader States, Variorum

container-title: Crusaders and Muslims in Twelfth-Century Syria
Malcolm Barber’s article, ‘Frontier Warfare in the Latin Kingdom of Jerusalem: The Campaign of Jacob’s Ford, 1178–9’, The Crusades and their Sources: Essays presented to Bernard Hamilton
deals with an important episode in the conflict. The Muslim angle is covered in huge detail in Malcolm Lyons and D.E.P
note: This book is, to put it mildly, hard work, but is well worth the effort because it offers the most definitive work on Saladin’s career to date, and makes use of narrative and hitherto ignored (and untranslated) documentary evidence. Anne-Marie Eddé’s Saladin, tr. Jane-Marie Todd, Belknap Harvard, Cambridge MA, 2011, is another weighty and erudite work, albeit one that is extremely well-written and provides a substantial amount of superb contextual material too. Carole Hillenbrand’s The Crusades: Islamic Perspectives, 1999, is a lighter overview.
publisher: Jackson, Saladin. The Politics of the Holy War, Cambridge University Press
title: cover two key aspects to good effect. Alan Murray has neatly collated the information on the True Cross in his article ‘Mighty against the Enemies of the Christ: The Relic of the True Cross in the Armies of the Kingdom of Jerusalem’, The Crusades and their Sources: Essays Presented to
Denys Pringle’s monumental The Churches of the Crusader Kingdom of Jerusalem

is a benchmark reference work on religious buildings in the Latin kingdom of Jerusalem. The period 1174–87 has received considerable attention from historians. On the Frankish side, Bernard Hamilton’s The Leper-king and his Heirs: Baldwin IV and the Crusader Kingdom of Jerusalem
is a clear overview. Peter Edbury’s article, ‘Propaganda and Faction in the Kingdom of Jerusalem: The Background to Hattin’

is a very important and effective paper that completely demolishes the old ‘hawks’ versus ‘doves’ idea. Jonathan Phillips reveals the settlers’ efforts to secure outside help at this time in Defenders of the Holy Land, 1996

note: although see also Smail’s Crusading Warfare 1097–1193,
title: The Battle of Hattin is best covered in Benjamin Kedar’s ‘The Battle of Hattin Revisited’
There is no good monograph on the Third Crusade, but the best account is in John Gillingham’s Richard I
enormously scholarly and original, yet readable and entertaining at the same
and Eddé’s Saladin, 2011 both carry a full account from the Muslim perspective. The Fourth Crusade is analysed to best effect by
The Fourth Crusade: The Conquest of Constantinople
offers a lively account of the campaign, while Thomas F. Madden provides excellent insight into the Venetian perspective with his Enrico Dandolo and the Rise of Venice
The Byzantine viewpoint is argued by Michael Angold, The Fourth Crusade: Event and Context

note: see E. Christiansen, The Northern Crusades, second edition, Penguin, Harmondsworth, 1997; Jerusalem in the North: Denmark and the Baltic
title: At the edges of this book, we have seen developments in crusading elsewhere and it is worth signposting a few important starting points

note: For Frankish Greece, see Nikos Chrissis, Crusading in Frankish Greece: A Study of Byzantine–Western Relations and Attitudes 1204–1282, Brepols, Turnout, 2013.
title: The Popes and the Baltic Crusades, 1147–1254
For the Children’s Crusade, see Gary Dickson’s superb The Children’s Crusade
For the Albigensian Crusade, see Michael Costen, The Cathars and the Albigensian Crusade
Lawrence Marvin, The Occitan War: A Military and Political History of the Albigensian Crusade, 1209–1218
For crusading in Iberia, see Purkis, Crusading Spirituality, 2008 noted earlier, and Joseph O’Callaghan, Reconquest and Crusade in Medieval Spain

container-title: The Crusades from the Perspective of the Byzantine and Muslim Worlds
title: Finally, the important subject of historiography is given a commanding overview by Giles Constable, ‘The Historiography of the Crusades’
Norman Housley’s excellent Contesting the Crusades
vigorously explores historians’ various interpretations of the crusades, while Christopher Tyerman’s The Debate on the Crusades
does much to trace the context for this evolution, as well as evaluating the strengths and weaknesses of various viewpoints
The History of the Holy War: Ambroise’s ‘Estoire de la guerre sainte’
